Graphical abstract Alumina supported mono and bimetallic Co and Fe catalysts, with different metal loading and different Co/Fe ratio, were used for decomposition reaction of ammonia to produce COx-free hydrogen in the microwave reactor system by mixing with mesoporous carbon. The structural and surface properties of the catalysts before and after being exposed to microwave radiation at the catalytic bed were examined by different techniques. Catalysts exhibited high catalytic performance in the microwave system, such that total conversion was achieved at 400 °C under the flow of ammonia (GHSV of 36,000 ml/gcat.h), while they showed negligible activity in the conventionally heated reactor system. Microwave exposure causes the formation of cobalt carbide and iron carbide in the structure of monometallic cobalt and monometallic iron catalysts, respectively. Moreover a phase transition from γ-alumina to α -alumina was recognized for both of them. Long term exposure to microwave further enhance the carbide formation that could be effective getting stable conversion values in time on stream experiments. While, alumina supported monometallic cobalt catalysts gave better yield than alumina supported monometallic iron catalysts in both of the systems, bimetallic catalysts showed better activity than monometallic catalysts, especially at temperatures lower than 400 °C. Keywords Alumina supported catalyst Cobalt Iron Ammonia decomposition Microwave reactor 1 Introduction Currently, world energy production mainly relies on the processes which are using fossil fuel sources. Greenhouse gas emission which occurs during these processes and the continuous growth of energy demand are the main motivation of the researches in the field of near future’s much cleaner and sustainable energy sources. Hydrogen is expected to play an important role, especially along with fuel cell technology, but safety in transportation and storage of hydrogen is a current concern since hydrogen has high flammability. Therefore, ammonia has been suggested as an important hydrogen carrier material in future’s power system due to its high hydrogen content (17.6 %) and high energy density (3,000 W h kg−1) as well as its ability to provide COx-free hydrogen for fuel cell applications [1–8]. On-site hydrogen production by decomposition of ammonia with an adequate rate and conversion is necessary especially for proton exchange fuel cell application. In the literature, there are various studies on ammonia decomposition reaction over different kind of catalysts. The mechanism of ammonia decomposition reaction mainly involves the following steps; (1) adsorption of ammonia on the active surface initiates the reaction; (2) H atoms that are released due to the NH bond cleavage of adsorbed ammonia molecule form molecular hydrogen and (3) molecular nitrogen is formed with the help of recombinative desorption of nitrogen adatoms [5]. Studies revealed that chemical properties of the metal used in the reaction and experimental conditions are determining factors for the rate limiting step. The recombination of the adsorbed nitrogen atoms that results in the desorption of N2 molecule and NH bond scission are some examples to the suggested rate limiting steps in the literature [5,1]. Ganley et al. [5], concluded that recombinative nitrogen desorption is the rate limiting step for Ru, Co, Fe and Ni catalysts so decomposition rate increases with an increase in nitrogen desorption rate. On the other hand, NH bond scission is indicated as being the rate limiting step for Rh, Ir, Pd, Pt, Cu catalysts. Among the studied metals, Ruthenium catalyst shows the highest activity. Indeed volcano-type relationship, which was prepared by using ammonia decomposition rate of different metals and their dissociative nitrogen binding energies by Boisen et al. [9], indicates that Ruthenium has optimum value, but, its high price and scarcity have triggered researches on much cheaper, readily available metals. In that respect, cobalt or nickel could be good alternative catalyst for ammonia decomposition reaction [6,9], however, recombinative desorption rate of adsorbed N atoms from the active sites of cheaper metals limits the activity of the catalysts in ammonia decomposition reaction, unless the reaction is run at reaction temperatures higher than 500 °C. Different catalysts such as the ones prepared with suitable promoters or synthesized using different support materials or being in the form of either transition metal carbides or nitrides have been studied to mimic the nitrogen binding energy of ruthenium under mild temperatures [6]. Another alternative strategy is developing bimetallic catalysts that could compete with precious metals since synergistic effects of two metals can improve the catalytic performance and plenty of work has been recognized for different reactions such as Fe-Co for NO oxidation [10], CoCu for selective hydrogenation of quinolines [11], Ni-Co for ethanol reforming reactions [12]. Application of bimetallic systems, such as Fe-Co, Co-Mo, Ni-Fe, in conventional heated reaction system was reviewed in a detail by Bell and Torrente-Murciano [6]. In recent years, alternative energy sources, such as plasma or microwave, have been considered to supply necessary heat to chemical reactions, especially for the endothermic ones [13,14]. Our previous studies that investigated the activity of the mesoporous carbon supported iron [15] and molybdenum [16] incorporated catalysts in microwave focused reaction system revealed that higher conversion values would be easily reached at a relatively lower reaction temperature compared with the conventional heating system due to superior properties of microwave heating system. Meanwhile, the effects of microwave energy on the structure of carbon supported catalysts were investigated and formation of iron carbide and molybdenum carbide during the reaction period was found to be one of the possible reasons of getting better activity in COx-free hydrogen production [15–17]. In these works, carbon was used as a support material to provide large surface area for active sites and it was also responsible for heating of the catalytic bed due to its high microwave absorption property. In the literature, application of microwave energy on ammonia decomposition reaction over different transition metals as well as different supports is very rare according to the best of our knowledge. In the present study, effects of microwave energy on the activity of alumina supported cobalt and iron incorporated monometallic and bimetallic catalysts in ammonia decomposition reaction were investigated. Results obtained from the microwave focused system were compared with the ones obtained from the conventionally heated system, moreover, changes observed in the structure of the catalysts were discussed. 2 Experimental studies 2.1 Preparation of alumina supported monometallic catalysts A wet impregnation procedure was followed in the preparation of alumina supported monometallic catalysts. Alumina oxide (Al2O3, Merck) was selected as the support material. Iron Nitrate (Fe(NO3)3.9H2O, Sigma Aldrichs 98 %) and Cobalt Nitrate Hexahydrate (Co(NO3)2.6H2O, Sigma Aldrichs 99.95 %) were selected as the metal precursors. The synthesis solution was prepared by dissolving 0.5 g of support material and the required amount of the metal precursor in 125 ml of deionized water, simultaneously. The weight % of metal (cobalt or iron) in the mixture of metal and alumina was changed between 5 and 15. Obtained solution was stirred in a temperature controlled magnetic stirrer at 50 °C for 24 h and then it was transferred into an oven which was set at 50 °C for 24 h in order to be fully dried. All the synthesized catalysts were calcined and reduced before the activity tests. Cobalt incorporated catalysts were thermally treated under nitrogen flow at 700 °C for 5 h and reduced using high purity hydrogen at 400 °C for 3 h while iron incorporated catalysts were thermally treated at 500 °C for 5 h and reduction process was carried out at 550 °C for 2 h. Catalysts were named as M (where M: Co or Fe)(X)@Al2O3, where X refers to the weight percentage of metal in the mixture of metal and alumina. 2.2 Preparation of alumina supported bimetallic catalysts Alumina supported bimetallic catalysts were prepared following nearly the same procedure that was given in the preparation of monometallic ones. The amount of alumina present in the synthesis solution was kept constant at 0.5 g and the amount of cobalt precursor and that of iron precursor was the same as the one used in the preparation of monometallic catalysts having 5 wt% metal loading. Totally, 0.131 g of cobalt precursor and 0.2 g of iron precursor was used for the preparation of this bimetallic catalyst and it was called as Co-Fe@Al2O3 (1:1). Synthesis solution was prepared by dissolving both of the metal precursors as well as the support material in one pot. All the synthesized bimetallic catalysts were thermally treated under the flow of nitrogen at a temperature of 700 °C for 5 h and reduction process was carried out under the flow of pure hydrogen at 550 °C for 2 h. Two other bimetallic catalysts were also prepared, one of them is Co-Fe@Al2O3 (1:2) at which Co metal loading was kept constant while Fe metal loading was done using 0.41 g of iron precursor which was actually exactly the same amount used in the preparation of 10 wt % Fe loaded monometallic catalyst. The other one, Co-Fe@Al2O3 (2:1), was prepared using 0.279 g of cobalt precursor (correspond to the amount of cobalt used in 10 wt % monometallic catalyst) keeping the amount of iron precursor at the same amount. 2.3 Characterization studies In order to determine the structural properties of the catalysts before and after the reaction different techniques were applied to the samples. Inductively Coupled Plasma (ICP) Technique was applied by the help of Perkin Elmer DRC II model ICP-OES equipment. Nitrogen physisorption analyses were carried out at 77 K via the Quantachrome Autosorb–6B instrument. X-Ray diffraction (XRD) analyses were performed by Rigaku Ultima IV diffractometer with a Cu K radiation source, operated at 40 kV and 30 mA. The diffractograms were recorded in the range 10–90° with steps of 0.02°. TEM images were collected by JEOL JEM 2100 F high resolution transmission electron microscope (HRTEM) with a maximum acceleration voltage of 200 kV. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy analysis of the synthesized samples were carried out on PHI-5000 Versaprobe using Al as the X-ray anode, with an excitation power of 17.6 W. The Raman spectroscopy analysis was carried out by Renishaw (InVia Ssystems). The system has a laser line of 532 nm with 1800 grooves/mm grating and spectral resolution of 3 cm−1. 2.4 Reaction studies over synthesized catalysts In this study, ammonia decomposition reaction was run in the microwave heated reactor system (MW) that constituted a microwave generator (SAIREM Company) (Fig. 1 ). Mesoporous carbon has a good microwave absorbing properties, which is necessary in microwave systems, so all the synthesized catalysts were physically mixed with mesoporous carbon in 1:1 ratio prior to reaction tests in the microwave heated reactor system. Quartz which is known as being transparent to microwaves was selected as the material of construction for the tubular reactors so that any contribution could be occurred due to the effect of microwave energy on tube was eliminated. Totally 0.1 g of catalyst-carbon mixture was loaded into the middle section of the quartz tube providing the catalytic bed portion in the reactor and this tubular reactor was placed in the cavity of the microwave system. Pure ammonia was used as feed and its flow rate was set to 60 ml/min. During the experiments, microwave power was directly focused to the catalytic bed and reaction temperature was adjusted in the range of 250−600 °C by changing the power source in the microwave system. Temperature measurements were done throughout the reactions with the help of an infrared pyrometer (Raytek M13). A Gas Chromatograph (SRI) equipped with TCD detector and Porapaq Q column was adapted to the reaction system and online measurements were done during the experiments. Effluent stream data were collected and after reaching steady state at a specified temperature, ammonia conversion (X) values were evaluated using the average of them keeping the error limits within ±5 %. All the synthesized catalysts were also run in the Conventional Heated Reactor System (C) that constituted a temperature controlled tubular electrical furnace as the heat source. Fresh catalyst, 0.1 g in weight, was loaded into quartz reactor and tested in a reaction temperature interval of 400–800 °C under the flow of pure ammonia with 60 ml/min. Analysis were carried out in the same manner as microwave heated reactor system. 3 Results and discussions 3.1 Characterization of the synthesized catalysts Alumina supported monometallic and bimetallic catalysts were successfully prepared following the wet impregnation procedure, supported by the results of ICP-OES analyses. Physical properties of all the synthesized catalysts were summarized in Table 1 . Nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms of the monometallic and bimetallic catalysts in their calcined form were presented in Figs. 2–4 . Alumina supported monometallic cobalt catalysts as well as pure alumina showed Type IV adsorption-desorption isotherms with H1 type hysteresis loop according to IUPAC classification, indicating mesoporous structure (Fig. 2a). This type of hysteresis typically shows parallel adsorption and desorption branches and narrow pore size distribution curves. As seen in Fig. 2a, the starting point of hysteresis was observed at P/Po value of 0.4 for Co(5)@Al2O3, Co(15)@Al2O3 and pure Al2O3 and it is known that catalysts showing very close starting points have similar pore size distribution curves, as seen in Fig. 2b. Indeed, monomodal pore size distribution curves ranging from 2.5 to 15 nm with an average value of 4.8 nm based on desorption branch, were recognized for these catalysts (Fig. 2b). Pure alumina had a BET surface area value of 140 m2/g while alumina supported monometallic cobalt catalysts showed BET surface area values changing from 114 to 99 m2/g. As seen in Fig. 2a, adsorbed volume of Co(15)@Al2O3 is lower than that of the catalysts having lower metal loading. Nitrogen physisorption studies of alumina supported monometallic cobalt catalysts revealed that increasing metal loading did not affect the type of isotherms, however, it resulted in a small decrease in the surface area as well as pore volume. Pore mouths blockages or deposition of some crystallites within the pores may be reason of this situation. Results of nitrogen physisorption analyses that were applied to alumina supported iron catalysts indicated Type IV adsorption-desorption isotherms with type H2 hysteresis loop, indicating mesoporous structure with interconnected pore systems (Fig. 3a). It is known that, pore size distribution derived from desorption branch is much affected by pore network effects than the one derived from adsorption branch in the case of H2 type hysteresis. Even though monomodal pore size distribution curve ranging from 2 nm to 30 nm with an average value of 4.88 nm was observed for Fe(5)Al2O3 catalyst; pore size distribution curves of the catalysts having higher metal loading were not monomodal (Fig. 3b). For this reason, pore size distribution curves of Fe(10)@Al2O3 and Fe(15)@Al2O3 catalysts were also prepared using adsorption branches and they were presented in Fig. 3b. It was seen that in the case of Fe(10)@Al2O3 catalyst, some of the pores centered around 2.5 nm and larger fraction of pores centered around 5.8 nm and in the case of Fe(15)@Al2O3 catalyst very small fraction of pores centered about 3.4 nm and larger fraction of pores centered around 6.5 nm and 18.5 nm. Those peaks could be realized in both adsorption and desorption branches so they could be defined as real pores. Multipoint BET surface area of Fe(10)@Al2O3 catalyst was found to be 83.61 m2/g which was lower than that of pure support Al2O3 as seen in Table 1, indicating that iron species would be distributed well and be located within the pores. However, increasing iron content of the synthesis solution may cause the formation of some agglomerated iron species so that larger fraction of them might locate at the exterior surface. This may explain higher surface area of Fe(15)@Al2O3 compared to other catalyts. Most probably, agglomerated species might be easily formed in the synthesis solution having this metal loading, however, a different situation was considered for the case of Fe(10)@Al2O3, which had the highest surface area among the alumina supported monometallic iron catalysts. In the latter case, formation of micropores which were centered at 2.5 nm and larger pores which were centered around 18.5 nm should be taken into account, since they might greatly contribute to the surface area, therefore it could be said that larger fraction of iron species may locate within the pores in this catalyst. Nitrogen physisorption analyses were also applied to alumina supported bimetallic catalysts and pore size distribution curves prepared using BJH desorption data were presented in Fig. 4. Alumina supported bimetallic catalyst Co-Fe@Al2O3 (1:1) gave a BJH desorption surface area of 159.6 m2/g. Remembering that, alumina supported monometallic Co catalyst prepared by using the same amount of cobalt in the synthesis solution, namely Co(5)@Al2O3, had a surface area of 154.8 m2/g. On the other hand, a significant difference observed between the surface area of monometallic Fe catalyst with 5 % metal loading (114 m2/g) and its counterpart bimetallic catalysts Co-Fe@Al2O3 (1:1) (159.6 m2/g). These results imply some possible structural changes due to the addition of second metal into the synthesis solution. Meanwhile, as seen in Table 1, increasing the cobalt content of the bimetallic catalyst resulted in a decrease in the surface area, such that Co-Fe@Al2O3 (2:1) which was prepared at higher cobalt loading keeping the iron metal content at a constant value, had a BJH desorption surface area of 135.8 m2/g and the mean of the pore size distribution curve shifted to the right. When the increase in iron content of the bimetallic catalyst was investigated by keeping the cobalt content constant, the mean of the pore size distiribution curve of Co-Fe@Al2O3 (1:2) exhibited a small shift to the right and it was seen that this catalyst had a BJH surface area of 169.4 m2/g. Lee and co-workers prepared Fe-Co/Alumina catalysts for the production of synthetic natural gas by co-precipitation procedure at different Fe/Co ratio and they found that addition of cobalt decreased the surface area of the catalysts while increased the pore diameter of them, similar to our results [18]. X-Ray diffractograms of Co(10)@Al2O3 catalyst at different states, i.e. calcined, reduced and spent, were the typical examples to those of alumina supported monometallic cobalt catalysts worked in the present study (Fig. 5 ). In all states, peaks observed at 2 Ө values of 39.42°, 45.84° and 66.80° belong to (222), (400) and (440) planes of γ-alumina cubic phase, respectively (ICDD Card No: 00-056-0457). Peaks present at 2 Ө values of 19.26°, 31.42°, 36.8°, 38.12°, 45.14°, 59.6°and 65.34° are the reflections of Co3O4 crystallites according to JCPDS Card 00-42-1467 [19–21]. After being reduced at 400 °C for 3 h under the flow of pure hydrogen, metallic cobalt specie was supposed to be present in the catalyst structure. It is known that reduction of cobalt oxide takes place in three steps; in the first one Co3O4 is reduced to CoO, in the second step CoO is reduced to metallic Co. Rahmati et al., (2018) carried out H2 temperature programmed reduction study on the alumina supported cobalt catalysts and they indicated that reduction of Co3O4 to CoO occurred in the temperature range of 200–250 °C (with a maximum of 214−219 °C) and reduction of CoO to metallic Co happened in the range of 300–440 °C (with a maximum of 360−380 °C). Finally, the last step is attributed to the reduction of cobalt aluminate spinel which occurs at temperatures higher than 700 °C [21]. Vosoughi et al. (2017) reported a broad temperature interval, i.e. 350−620 °C, for reduction of CoO to Co crystallites for alumina supported cobalt catalysts and they mentioned that interaction between cobalt and alumina support could be effective on the reducibility of cobalt species. Either strongly bonded Co3O4 or CoO species to the alumina support or embedded cobalt ions within alumina lattice could be the reason of hardly reducible cobalt species [20]. Metallic cobalt could be identified with a (111) reflection peak observed at 2 Ө value of 44° according to card JCPDS 15-0806, however it is difficult to distinguish this peak in the X-Ray diffraction pattern of reduced sample. The size of Co3O4 crystal present in the calcined form of the Co@Al2O3(10) catalyst was found as 7.4 nm from XRD data and the crystals which are about 20 nm can be clearly recognized in HRTEM analysis of this sample as well as its counter part bimetallic one (Fig. 6 ). Therefore, strong interaction between alumina support with small Co3O4 may be the reason of cobalt oxide crystallites observed in the reduced form of Co@Al2O3(10) sample. Results of XRD analyses correspond to Fe@Al2O3(10) catalyst in different forms are given in Fig. 7 and they are representative of alumina supported monometallic iron catalysts synthesized in this work. As in the case of monometallic cobalt catalysts, γ-alumina was the major form of the alumina present in both calcined and reduced form of the monometallic iron catalysts with the peaks at 2 Ө values of 37.6°, 46.10° and 67.24°. α-Fe2O3 crystal was mainly recognized according to JCPDS card no. 33-664 with low intensity in both calcined an reduced form of the catalysts [22]. High intensity peaks that were seen at 2 Ө values of 44.86°, 65.32° and 82.62° in the diffraction lines of reduced sample correspond to metallic iron according to JCPDS card No.654899 (Fig. 7). The presence of iron oxide species in the structure of reduced sample could be explained with either necessity of higher temperatures for reduction such as over than 600 °C [23,24,17] or oxidation of samples due to air exposure before the XRD measurements. The Raman spectrums of alumina supported monometallic and bimetallic Co and Fe catalysts in their calcined form were presented in Fig. 8 . The Raman spectrum of alumina supported Co catalyst showed five peaks at around 191, 478, 519, 610 and 683 cm−1. It is known that Co3O4 crystal, which is a spinel structure, has five peaks for A1g, Eg and 3 F2g virational modes [25,18] and the peaks at 190, 454, 511, 600 and 666 cm−1 were reported for undoped and doped Co3O4 crystals [25]. So, these peaks confirm the presence Co3O4 structure within alumina supported monometallic cobalt catalysts. As stated by XRD analysis, α-Fe2O3 (hematite) was expected in monometallic iron catalyst but its intensity was very low as seen in Fig. 7. It is reported that Raman spectra of hematite (α-Fe2O3) has A1g modes at 225 and 498 cm−1, Eg modes at 247, 293, 299, 412, 613 cm−1 [26,27,18]. Hematite is also known as antiferromagnetic material and having a peak at around 1320 cm−1 is a feature of it [26]. Noting that loss in crystallinity causes line boradining, shift in peak position and formation of less intensity peaks in Raman spectrums [26,27]. Based on these knowledges, it could be said that peaks correspond A1g and Eg modes between 200−300 cm−1 and a broad band seen at 1309 cm−1 (which was not presented in this figure) indicate hematite structure. It is known that CoFe2O4 spinel ferrite crystal, which could be seen in Fe-Co bimetallic systems [18], has Raman modes at about 198, 297, 461, 558, 604 and 680 cm−1 [28]. The first four bands are assigned to T2g and Eg Raman modes and the last two are assigned to A1g Raman modes,i.e., the band A1g(2) which is seen at 604 cm−1 is being the shoulder of A1g(1) which is present at 680 cm−1 band. A shift in wavelength could be occurred due to the change in particle size and cation redistribution [28]. In the work of Wang and coworkers [29], it was reported that the intensity of A1g(1) and A1g(2) bands were very close to each other in Raman spectra of Co3-xFexO4 crystals having Fe/Co ratio close to 1 and A1g(2) mode was hardly seen in Co3-xFexO4 crystals having Fe/Co ratio close to 4. Thus, the Raman spectrums of alumina supported bimetallic catalysts are interpreted by the possible formation of cobalt ferrite (CoFe2O4) nanoparticles. 3.2 Ammonia decomposition reaction studies Ammonia decomposition reaction was run with alumina supported monometallic cobalt catalysts in the conventionally heated reactor system (showed with “C”) and in the microwave heated reactor system (showed with “MW”) under the flow of pure ammonia (60 ml/min) and results were presented in Fig. 9 . In the case of conventionally heated reactor system, activities of the catalysts were negligible at a reaction temperature equal or less than 500 °C. According to the volcano-type relationship cobalt is highly active metal in terms of nitrogen binding energies [9,5] and activity of cobalt based catalysts in ammonia decomposition reaction was investigated by different groups considering the role of support or the size of the particles and so on [30,2,22]. For instance, Gu et al. [22], worked with Fe, Co, and Ni nanoparticles dispersed in alumina matrix and they concluded that with the addition of aluminum, agglomeration of metal was suppressed during the reaction so that nanoparticles could be stabilized and higher conversion values could be achieved in ammonia decomposition reaction. In their work, 100 % ammonia conversion was reported at 600 °C with a space velocity of 36,000 cm3gcat−1 h−1 NH3 flow for alumina supported cobalt catalyst having 90 M % metal. Moreover the catalyst having 10 M % metal showed 100 % ammonia conversion at 650 °C with a space velocity of 18,000 cm3gcat−1 h−1 NH3 flow [22]. In our study, total conversion was achieved at 650 °C using alumina supported monometallic cobalt catalysts having 10 % metal loading with a GHSVNH3: 36,000 ml/gcat.h when conventionally heated reactor system was used. Among the synthesized monometallic cobalt catalysts, Co(5)@Al2O3 which had the lowest metal loading showed the lowest activity. On the other hand, very similar conversion values were obtained with Co(10)@Al2O3 and Co(15)@Al2O3. Thus, increasing metal loading may provide more active sites for the reaction, however, further increase in metal loading might cause formation of some agglomerated species which results in lower activity in the reaction. In this system, 10 % metal loading would be an optimum loading for getting higher activity. Equilibrium limitation for ammonia decomposition reaction, which is about 99 % at 400 °C, indicates the possibility of getting higher conversion values over alumina supported catalysts. When the reaction was carried out in the microwave heated reactor system using the same catalysts, much better results were achieved as followed in Fig. 9. Ammonia was converted with a value of about 10–18 %, even at 250 °C under the flow of pure ammonia (60 ml/min). When the reaction temperature was increased to 350 °C by adjusting microwave power rate, conversion values over 97 % were achieved. There is a steadily increase in ammonia conversion values with an increase in metal loading. Wang and coworkers [14] run ammonia decomposition reaction using Co/r´-Al2O3 catalysts with dielectric barrier discharge plasma and they reported 95.2 % ammonia conversion at 450 °C with 40 ml/min of ammonia flow and only 15 % ammonia conversion for conventional case. These results indicate that alternative heating routes greatly enhance the activity of alumina supported cobalt catalysts in ammonia decomposition reaction. Activities of alumina supported monometallic iron catalysts were presented in Fig. 10 . Results obtained from the conventionally heated reactor system showed that activities of the catalysts were not significant below 550 °C and total conversion was achieved at about 750 °C. An increase in the metal loading and in the reaction temperature gradually enhanced the ammonia conversion. Gu et al. [22] reported that FeAl catalysts having 90 % metal loading gave 86 % ammonia conversion at 600 °C with 36,000 cm3gcat−1 h−1 NH3 flow and catalysts having 10 % metal loading gave 100 % conversion at 650 °C with 18,000 cm3gcat−1 h−1 NH3 flow. In our study, catalysts having metal loading higher than 15 % were not tested but it might be suggested that higher metal loading might increase the conversion of ammonia to much higher values by considering the trend in the activity curves retrieved from conventional system. Microwave heated reactor system favored ammonia conversion over alumina supported iron catalysts and total conversion was obtained at 400 °C, as in Fig. 10. Unlike in the case of conventional heated reactor system, much higher conversion values reaching to 80 % were achieved at 350 °C in this system. Significantly better activity of alumina supported catalysts in microwave heated reactor system in comparison to conventionally heated reactor system (Figs. 9 and 10) could be explained with the diversity in the heating mechanism of these two systems. It is known that microwave ovens, having a frequency value of 2.45 GHz, have been generally used for food processing and for some homogeneous reactions and heat is generated by direct conversion of electromagnetic energy within a few seconds in these systems [31,32]. However, in the conventionally heated reactor systems, heat is generated via resistance of tubular furnace and it is transferred through the walls and the cavity of the furnace until reaching to the sample, by means of convection and conduction mechanisms. Therefore, rate enhancement, higher conversion and better yields were reported for different heterogeneous reactions due to the selective, volumetric and non-contact heating properties of microwave heating [31–35], supporting our observations. Another point that should be considered related to the microwave heated reactor system is the formation of hot spots within the bed. Since the local temperature of hot spots is expected to be higher than the overall bed temperature, an increase the conversion of ammonia is supposed to be occurred [36,37]. Moreover, it is known that N2, other product of ammonia decomposition reaction, enhances the formation of hot spots of higher temperature [38]. As mentioned previously, Guo and co-workers applied plasma catalysis to ammonia decomposition reaction [13]. They applied 15NH3 isotope tracing and optical emission spectroscopy experiments using Fe-based catalysts and they concluded that plasma resulted in a decrease in the desorption temperature of Nad so that higher activity could be obtained at lower reaction temperature [13]. Guo and coworkers also used dielectric barrier discharge plasma over fumed SiO2 supported Co catalyst at 450 °C under 40 ml/min of ammonia flow and they reported 99.2 % ammonia conversion via electric heat released by the plasma, whereas, 20 % ammonia conversion via electric heating furnace. When the same study was repeated for fumed SiO2 supported Fe catalysts, 71.7 % ammonia conversion was obtained under the former case and 12.2 % ammonia conversion was reported for the latter one [14]. As indicated previously, recombinative nitrogen desorption is rate limiting steps for Co and Fe catalysts and decomposition rate increases with an increase in nitrogen desorption rate [5]. Thus, we are expecting that application of microwave might accelerate the rate limiting step, as mentioned in plasma-catalyst synergy mentioned in the previous works. Microwave-specific effect was also discussed in the literature to explain getting higher activity in microwave focused reactions [39,40]. Stiegman and co-workers proposed that microwaves not only selectively heat the substrate but also have dramatic effects on the primary thermokinetic steps of the process to yield significantly different equilibrium properties, resulting in higher conversion values at lower reaction temperatures in heterogeneous reaction systems. They studied the Boudouard reaction, water gas shift reaction and carbon hydrogen reaction under microwave irradiation in comparison to conventional convective heating. For Boudouard reaction, they reported lower apparent activation energy and lower enthalpy of reaction under microwave irradiation. Enhanced production in synthesis gas from the steam–carbon reactions and in H2 from the carbon–hydrogen reaction was also discussed in their work. This hypothesis would give some insights to explain getting higher conversion values at lower reaction temperatures in ammonia decomposition reaction and should be verified in further studies. Activity studies revealed that alumina supported monometallic cobalt catalysts gave better yield than alumina supported monometallic iron catalysts not only in conventionally heated reactor system but also in microwave heated reactor systems, especially at lower reaction temperatures, as indicated in the literature. In a detailed work of Ganley et al., [5], the catalytic activity of 13 different metals on ammonia decomposition reaction in a conventionally heating system was examined and it was reported that monometallic Co gave better activity than monometallic Fe catalyst and the nitrogen desorption was the rate limiting step for both of them [5]. Lendzion-Bielun et al. [30] studied the kinetics of synthesis and decomposition of ammonia over iron and cobalt catalysts and they revealed that activation energy of ammonia decomposition reaction over cobalt and iron catalyst was 111 kJ/mol and 138 kJ/mol, respectively. Apart from these studies which were carried out in conventional reactor, higher synergetic capability of Co in comparison to Fe for plasma driven ammonia decomposition reaction was reported [14]. Variation in activation energy of rate determining steps under microwave energy will be evaluated with the further studies. In our previous work, mesoporous silicate structured cobalt catalyst was prepared using cobalt nitrate and reaction studies that had been carried out in the conventionally heated reactor system, showed 75 % ammonia conversion at 600 °C and total conversion at 700 °C under pure ammonia flow (GHSV: 36,000 ml/gcat.h). That catalyst had a BET surface area of 640 m2/g catalyst and an average pore size of 2.7 nm. In the present study, synthesized alumina supported monometallic catalyst had a surface area value about 110 m2/g and an average pore size of 4.8 nm. It is known that the accessibility of Co species in the catalyst structure which is in turn related to the texture and porosity of support matrix affected the catalytic activity [19] and this may explain the difference between the activity of alumina supported and mesoporous silicate structured cobalt catalysts in conventionally heated reactor system. Microwave heated reactor system was also used for determining the activity of mesoporous silicate structured cobalt catalyst under the same condition. When the catalyst was not mixed with mesoporous carbon, reaction did not take place since it was not possible to heat up the catalytic bed. Than experiment was repeated by using a mixture of catalyst and mesoporous carbon in 1:1 ratio and about 35 % ammonia conversion was seen at 400 °C and total conversion was achieved at 450 °C. It could be said that alumina supported catalyst show better activity in microwave heated system as well, based on activity data collected at lower reaction temperatures. Time on stream experiments were carried out using Fe(10)@Al2O3 and Co(15)@Al2O3 catalysts in the microwave heated reactor system with ammonia flow of 60 ml/min and their results were presented in Figs. 11 and 12 , respectively. Microwave generator was set to the necessary power to obtain the reaction temperature of 400 °C and the system was maintained at the same conditions throughout the experiment without removing catalyst. Stability tests were performed in 5 runs, each of being 8 h and between each run generator was shut down and then opened again. Remembering that, Fe(10)@Al2O3 and Co(15)@Al2O3 catalysts showed total conversion under these reaction conditions. Results obtained with Fe(10)@Al2O3 showed that the variation in the activity of the catalyst was negligible for this time duration, i.e. ammonia conversion values were obtained between 99.8 % and 98.5 %. Similar behavior was observed for Co(15)@Al2O3, all results were between 99.8 % and 99.5 %. Theseimplied that application of microwave to the catalysts in different time interval did not affect their activity. Zhang and co-workers tested CNTs supported monometallic Co and Fe catalysts in conventionally heated reactor system and they reported deactivation over these catalysts. After being used at 600 °C with 36,000 ml of NH3 g−1 h−1 for 1000 min, a significant decrease in the activity of Fe catalyst was seen, i.e. only 45 % of initial activity remained, due to the sintering of nanoparticles [41]. In the present study, this long-term stability may be attributed to suppressing of sintering or agglomeration by the effect of microwave energy. Catalysts which had already been used in microwave heated reactor system (MW-spent) were re-used in conventionally heated reactor system and their activities were compared with the activity of their fresh form. Reaction temperature was changed from 400 to 750 °C, ammonia flow was set to 60 ml/min and the weight of catalytic bed was 0.1 g in conventionally heated reactor system. As seen Fig. 13 , both fresh and MW-spent form of Co@Al2O3 and Fe@Al2O3 catalysts showed negligible acitivity below 550 °C. Eventhough activities of fresh catalysts seem to be higher than that of MW-spent catalysts in the conventional system, it should be noted that MW-spent catalysts contained less amount of metal species. Remembering that experiments were carried out by mixing catalyst with mesoporous carbon (1:1 ratio) in microwave heated reactor system. Activities of the alumina supported monometallic catalysts were tested in the microwave heated reactor system at different space velocity as well. Results of reaction experiments carried out with an ammonia flow of 30 ml/min were given in Fig.14 a and b for monometallic cobalt and monometallic iron catalyst, respectively, in comparison to the results obtained with an ammonia flow of 60 ml/min. Monometallic cobalt catalyst having 15 % metal loading gave 91 % ammonia conversion and monometallic iron catalyst having 10 % metal loading gave 85 % ammonia conversion at 300 °C. 3.3 Characterization studies of spent catalysts Results of XRD analyses that were applied to the spent forms of alumina supported monometallic cobalt catalyst, are presented in Fig. 5. When the alumina supported monometallic cobalt catalyst was used in conventionally heated system, γ-alumina phase was still observed. Cobalt species seen in the structure of C-spent catalyst were metallic cobalt and cobalt oxide in low intensity. The latter one was formed most probably due to the oxidation of catalyst before the XRD analysis. As mentioned previously, synthesized catalysts were used in microwave heated reactor system by mixing with mesoporous carbon, for this reason graphite-like carbon structure was determined with peaks at 2 Ө values of 25.7°, 26.4°, 42.7°, 52.7°, 57.5°, 68.5° (JCPDS card 00-041-1487) in the X-Ray diffraction patterns of the MW-spent catalyst. Differently from the conventional heating, microwave energy which was sent to the catalytic bed induced a change in the alumina phase of the catalytic bed, i.e., a phase transition occurred from γ-alumina to α -alumina. Diffraction peaks which were observed at 2 Ө values of 25.88°, 35.18°, 37.88°, 43.98°, 52.64°, 57.5°, 66.86° and 68.12° were correspond to the α -alumina phase according to ICDD 46–1212 [37]. Indeed, temperature values over than 950° were reported for the formation of the α -alumina phase under conventional heating procedure [42], however, Co(10)@Al2O3 catalyst was run up to 600 °C in microwave heated reactor before the XRD analysis. This means that α -phase could be obtained at much lower temperature values under the effect of microwave energy. Peaks that were seen at 2 Ө values of 37° and 2 Θ values in the range of 43–45° might be explained with crystals of Co2C as well as metallic cobalt but these peaks were coincidence with the peaks correspond to α -alumina and mesoporous carbon. In order to clarify the presence of cobalt carbide species, XPS analysis was applied to MW-spent catalyst. As seen in Fig. 15 , Co 2p1/2 and 2p3/2 peaks were seen at 796.2 and 782.2 eV and they were correspond to cobalt oxide species [43,11,44]. Noting that, this is not an in-situ analyses and sample was exposed to air before the measurement. It is known that metallic cobalt is easily oxidized and cobalt carbide is highly unstable in air, so it is difficult to see the peaks attributed to cobalt carbide which are expected at 778.3 eV [44]. On the other hand, C 1s spectrum of MW-spent sample presented in Fig. 15, suggests two types of carbon species. The peak which is observed at 284.6 eV is explained with the presence of polyaromatic carbon and the other C 1s peak which is seen at 283.0 eV is attributed to carbidic carbon [45]. Trinh et al., reported that the peak at 283 eV most likely correspond to the surface carbide phase. Zhang and coworkers also indicated C 1s peak at 283.3 eV for carbidic carbon by referring to the reported values for carbide species on different cobalt catalysts which were 282.9–283.3 eV [44]. Therefore, possible formation of cobalt carbide under microwave energy is supported by XPS analysis. X-Ray diffraction analyses corresponding to the spent forms of the alumina supported monometallic iron catalyst were presented in Fig. 7. Metallic iron was still present in the C-spent catalyst with high intensity whereas iron oxide species which had been seen in reduced form disappeared. Since the reaction proceed up to 800 °C, oxide species could have been reduced at this condition. Peaks observed at 2 Ө values of 25.74°, 43.50°, 52.84°, 57.72° and 68.40° in the X-Ray diffraction patterns of the MW-spent sample indicated carbon structure which had been present in the catalytic bed in order to absorb microwave. A phase transition between γ-alumina to α -alumina took place in the structure of MW-spent catalyst. As seen in Fig. 7, metallic iron crystal was not determined in MW-spent sample but new peaks were recognized. Metal carbide species were expected to be formed due to the effect of microwave on the catalytic bed [15]. Peaks which are present at 2 Ө values of 35°, 38°,41°,43°,48°,52° and 58° correspond to a mixture of iron carbide namely Fe2C and Fe5C2 according to JCPDS card 00-036-1249 and JCPDS card 00-020-0508, respectively. On the other side, it is known that iron forms stable nitrides [46,1,22]. Unlike X-Ray diffraction pattern of C-spent catalyt, X-Ray diffraction pattern of MW-spent catalyt have peaks indicating Fe3N1.2 according to JCPDS card 01-077-8707. Indeed, it was reported that nitriding process that could be applied at elevated temperatures (higher than 500 °C) for a long time duration (from 20 to 80 h) caused formation of nitride species [46]. Therefore, it is not likely to get nitride specie as a result of 8 h reaction in the conventionally heated medium. On the other side, Tong et al., (2009) reported nitridation of nanostructured surface layer at 300 °C therefore it could be suggested that microwave irradiation may cause surface layer nitride formation especially at hot points [46]. Catalysts those were used for time on stream experiments in microwave heated reactor system were investigated via XRD analyses and the results were presented in Fig. 16 . Metallic cobalt specie which was observed in the structure of the catalyst after being used in short term experiment (Fig. 5) dissappeared completely and cobalt carbide became the only cobalt specie in the structure of the catalyst after being used in longer time duration. Meanwhile, iron carbide crystal with high intensity was still seen in X-ray diffractogram of alumina supported iron catalyst which was used in longer time duration. According to these results, we may come to conclusion that metallic cobalt and metallic iron species are the active species for ammonia decomposition. Due to superior properties of microwave system activity of catalysts increases and microwave energy also provides formation of cobalt carbide and iron carbide species, which enhance the activity as well. 3.4 Activity of bimetallic catalysts In order to see the synergetic effects of Co and Fe during the reaction, alumina supported bimetallic catalysts were run in microwave heated reactor system with an ammonia flow of 60 ml/min. Obtained results were presented in Fig. 17 with the results of counterpart monometallic catalysts. All of the synthesized catalysts achieved total conversion at a reaction temperature of 400 °C. Among the synthesized catalysts, Co-Fe@Al2O3 (1:1) and Co-Fe@Al2O3 (2:1) showed better activity than Co@Al2O3(5) and Fe@Al2O3(5) especially at temperatures lower than 400 °C, indicating that using cobalt and iron species together created a synergy and enhanced the activity. X-ray diffraction patterns of the bimetallic catalysts after being used in the microwave heated reactor (MW-spent) are shown in Fig. 18 . While iron nitride specie was seen in the structure of alumina supported monometallic iron catalysts whether it was used for one run (Fig. 7) or used in TOS experiments (Fig. 12), it was not determined in the structure of the MW-spent bimetallic catalysts. Zhang et al., indicated formation of several metallic Fe-Co alloy phases with different Fe/Co ratio, such as Fe3Co7, FeCo, Fe7Co3 at 2 Ө values in the range of 44.7–45.1° for their carbon nanotube encapsulated Fe-Co alloy nanoparticles [41]. Activities of these catalysts were found to be as high as that of pure cobalt case and higher than the activities of pure iron case in conventionally heated reaction system due the unusual synergism in alloying. It was mentioned that during the formation of a surface Fe-Co bond, the electron transfer from electron rich Co, having one more d band electron, to Fe happen, and this change in electronic properties of Fe can enhance the desorption of adsorbed nitrogen atoms from the surface and may decrease the activation energy. Indeed, stability of Co was improved with alloying with Fe and metallic alloy was indicated as the active phase for Fe-Co samples [41]. In the present study, it can be suggested to see FeCo alloy in the structure of bimetallic catalysts considering the peak around 45.7° in the X-ray diffraction patterns, but it is difficult to decide whether this peak is attributed to metallic Fe or FeCo. In another work, which was carried out by Lee et al., [18], Fe-Co/alumina samples with different Fe/Co ratio were prepared following co-precipitation procedure and iron oxide ( α -Fe2O3), cobalt oxide and CoFe2O4 were the species observed in the calcined form of the catalysts. They founded that addition of cobalt to the iron catalyst enhanced the dispersion of iron oxidesand caused the formation of cobalt ferrite instead of Co3O4 [18]. Reduction of CoFe2O4 to metallic Fe and FeCo alloy was observed at temperature in the range from 300 to 600 °Cdepending on the Co content of the catalysts. In the X-Ray diffraction patterns of all MW-spent bimetallic catalysts, peaks at 2 Ө values of 30.82, 33.32, 35.82, 49.68, 54.32, 57.3 and 63.24° were belong to CoFe2O4 crystallite, which was also supported by Raman analysis. Unlike iron carbide, it is difficult to evaluate the cobalt carbide in these catalysts. Most probably, formation of cobalt ferrite instead of cobalt oxide inhibit the formation of cobalt carbide, since metallic cobalt is expected to form cobalt carbide with the mesoporous carbon during the ammonia decomposition reaction. As seen in Fig. 18, peaks corresponding to CoFe2O4 crystallite has higher intensity in the structure of Co-Fe@Al2O3(1:2) than the other bimetallic catalysts. Combining with the activity data presented in Fig. 17, it can be said that cobalt ferrite crystals having smaller size would be effective in getting higher acitivity. 4 Conclusions In the present study, alumina supported mono and bimetallic Co and Fe catalysts were prepared following a wet impregnation procedure and they were tested in microwave heated reactor system. Activity studies revealed that alumina supported monometallic cobalt catalysts gave better yield than alumina supported monometallic iron catalysts not only in the conventional system but also in microwave heated reactor system especially at lower reaction temperatures. Due to the superior properties of microwave system, total conversion values were achieved at 350 °C–400 °C over monometallic catalysts GHSV NH3: 36,000 ml/gcat.h unlike conventional system. Moreover they kept their activity under longer period of time which might be attributed to suppressing of sintering or agglomeration by the effect of microwave energy. For bimetallic catalysts, cobalt and iron species created a synergy and enhanced the activity. Microwave exposure caused a phase transition from γ-alumina to α -alumina for both of the monometallic catalysts and resulted in the formation of either cobalt or iron carbide. Long term exposure to microwave did not affect the crystal structure of these catalysts; and it can be said that carbide formation could enhance the reaction for longer time interval. coredata.dc:description: Alumina supported mono and bimetallic Co and Fe catalysts, with different metal loading and different Co/Fe ratio, were used for decomposition reaction of ammonia to produce COx-free hydrogen in the microwave reactor system by mixing with mesoporous carbon. The structural and surface properties of the catalysts before and after being exposed to microwave radiation at the catalytic bed were examined by different techniques. Catalysts exhibited high catalytic performance in the microwave system, such that total conversion was achieved at 400 °C under the flow of ammonia (GHSV of 36,000 ml/gcat.h), while they showed negligible activity in the conventionally heated reactor system. Microwave exposure causes the formation of cobalt carbide and iron carbide in the structure of monometallic cobalt and monometallic iron catalysts, respectively. Moreover a phase transition from γ-alumina to α -alumina was recognized for both of them. Long term exposure to microwave further enhance the carbide formation that could be effective getting stable conversion values in time on stream experiments. While, alumina supported monometallic cobalt catalysts gave better yield than alumina supported monometallic iron catalysts in both of the systems, bimetallic catalysts showed better activity than monometallic catalysts, especially at temperatures lower than 400 °C.
coredata.dc:title: Performance of Co-Fe@Alumina catalysts in comparison to monometallic Co@Alumina and Fe@Alumina catalysts for microwave assisted COx-free hydrogen production
